This is not relevant to whether there is a net domestic gain from the tariff. The tariff hurts domestic consumers. Unless the gain from the tariff exceeds the loss to consumers, national welfare will decrease.

choices.itemBody: A. It must have a comparative advantage in the production of the imported good
B. The deadweight loss must be smaller than the benefit of its improving terms of trade
C. It must auction the import licenses for a fee to offset the decline in the consumer surplus

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Quant-Chua-15
entry.itemBody: An analyst estimates the probabilities of three possible economic scenarios and the probabilities of a stock having a positive or a negative return in each scenario. These scenarios are best represented by a:

answerFeedback.0f336473-3b00-4c2d-873b-0a7e8b2a1509: Incorrect because a tree-map is a graphical tool to display categorical data. It consists of a set of colored rectangles to represent distinct groups, and the area of each rectangle is proportional to the value of the corresponding group. Additional dimensions of categorical data can be displayed by nested rectangles.
answerFeedback.5e10fbbf-1a18-44b9-9c84-73fed1831899: Incorrect because the probability estimates are for two discrete random variables, not one continuous random variable. A probability function specifies the probability that the random variable takes on a specific value. For continuous random variables, the probability function is called the probability density function (pdf), or just the density.
answerFeedback.d84c50dd-5869-4396-adb3-6cfdbf8b8529: Correct because probabilities for different scenarios and different outcomes are best represented using a tree diagram.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Crutu-09
entry.itemBody: An inflation-targeting central bank most likely has a medium-term inflation target sufficiently:

answerFeedback.4aae6f20-1217-4057-809e-b4077259a10a: Correct because an inflation-targeting framework normally has a clear, symmetric and forward-looking medium-term inflation target, sufficiently above 0 percent to avoid the risk of deflation but low enough to ensure a significant degree of price stability.
answerFeedback.75aefed3-f975-4242-a4e7-2c07e007f16d: Incorrect because an inflation-targeting framework normally has a clear, symmetric and forward-looking medium-term inflation target, sufficiently above 0 percent to avoid the risk of deflation but low enough to ensure a significant degree of price stability.
answerFeedback.d2943791-f2a9-4202-b769-7018d80de568: Incorrect because an inflation-targeting framework normally has a clear, symmetric and forward-looking medium-term inflation target, sufficiently above 0 percent to avoid the risk of deflation but low enough to ensure a significant degree of price stability.

choices.itemBody: A. below zero to avoid the risk of deflation but high enough to ensure price stability.
B. above zero to avoid the risk of deflation but low enough to ensure price stability.
C. above zero to avoid the risk of inflation and high enough to ensure price stability.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Econ-Elliott-29
entry.itemBody: Assuming wages and prices are stable, which of the following policy combinations most likely leads to an increase in the private sector's share of GDP?

answerFeedback.19a335f1-13c5-4265-98a6-9dbb2b382b91: Incorrect, because under easy fiscal policy/tight monetary policy we have higher output and higher interest rates, and government spending (not the private sector) will be a larger proportion of overall national income.
answerFeedback.38a25296-b119-4067-985c-f55382dd3f59: Incorrect, because if both fiscal and monetary policy are easy, then the joint impact will be highly expansionary leading to—lower interest rates (at least if the monetary impact is larger), and growing private and public sectors, without the private sector's share of GDP growing.
answerFeedback.56072de4-a61e-4fa0-9d84-c790032ebfd1: Correct because with tight fiscal policy/easy monetary policy: If a fiscal contraction is accompanied by expansionary monetary policy and low interest rates, then the private sector will be stimulated and will rise as a share of GDP, while the public sector will shrink.

choices.itemBody: A. Easy fiscal and easy monetary policy
B. Tight fiscal and easy monetary policy

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06630
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information:

Account 1 Account 2 Account 3
Stated annual interest rate 6.1% 6.3% 6.2%
Compounding frequency Daily Annual Quarterly

If a $1,000 deposit is made today, the future value in one year will be greatest for:

answerFeedback.0d518d39-ece7-4fbb-8b46-475eb54df571: Incorrect because Account 3 will have the greatest future value in one year. Despite Account 1's more frequent compounding, the lower stated annual interest rate results in a lower future value when compared to Account 3.
answerFeedback.86c326cd-d832-490f-963b-54c84d505b79: Incorrect because Account 3 will have the greatest future value in one year. Despite Account 2's higher stated annual interest rate, the less frequent compounding results in a lower future value when compared to Account 3.
answerFeedback.e322c5d5-53b4-4fbb-889f-59dc1b150107: Correct because the account with the highest effective annual rate (EAR) will have the greatest future value in one year. The effective annual rate is calculated as follows: EAR = (1 + Periodic interest rate)m – 1. The periodic interest rate is the stated annual interest rate divided by m, where m is the number of compounding periods in one year. The EAR of Account 3 is (1 + 0.062/4)4 – 1 = 0.06346 = 6.35%, compared to (1 + 0.061/365)365 – 1 = 0.06289 = 6.29% for Account 1 and 6.30% for Account 2. The resulting future values are: $1,063.46 for Account 3, compared to $1,062.89 for Account 1 and $1,063.00 for Account 2.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516070
entry.itemBody: At year end, a company has non-convertible debt, ordinary shares, and employee stock options outstanding. The company’s capital structure is considered to be:

answerFeedback.247b625f-29b2-481d-b9b5-41a2f73d3688: Incorrect because the existence of debt does not make the capital structure complex. The structure is complex because the employee stock options are convertible into ordinary shares.
answerFeedback.8ce24ebb-b74a-4a0d-ba9e-3ef1550cf326: Incorrect because a capital structure is considered complex if the company has issued any financial instruments that are potentially convertible into common stock, such as employee stock options. It does not matter if these instruments are antidilutive.
answerFeedback.9b1ec1ea-42c0-4935-a0f6-79406331685c: Correct because when a company has issued any financial instruments that are potentially convertible into common stock, it is said to have a complex capital structure. Potentially convertible financial instruments include convertible bonds, convertible preferred stock, employee stock options, and warrants. Any antidilutive effect of a convertible security relates to the calculation of EPS and is not part of the distinction of simple vs. complex capital structure.

choices.itemBody: A. simple, if the options are antidilutive.
B. complex, because the company has both debt and equity.
C. complex, because the options are convertible into ordinary shares.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608367
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely to signal manipulation of financial reporting for a large, diversified company?

answerFeedback.35498fed-2ba7-45ef-bb53-a2002b6efb93: Incorrect because accounting policies must be changed to comply with new accounting standards. Changes for this purpose are not suspect.
answerFeedback.e7063119-502e-4fed-9312-bddf74d703f2: Correct because a history of unusual expense items may indicate a pattern of management manipulating the way investors perceive operating income performance. Repeated use of the “unusual” or “non-recurring” category decreases the value of this classification and suggests that management may be trying to manipulate users’ perceptions of sustainable profitability levels.
answerFeedback.efeccefc-2fab-48c1-91f1-c24dcb03ad59: Incorrect because diversified companies include a mix of businesses and, depending on that mix, may or may not be expected to have similar operating margins.

choices.itemBody: A. A history of large expense items classified as unusual
B. Operating margins out of line with other diversified companies
C. Changes in accounting policies to reflect new accounting standards

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-CorpIssuers-Niininen-03
entry.itemBody: According to capital allocation principles, managers should ignore:

answerFeedback.497cbed7-fdbf-4d59-8808-f8a0993bcf2b: Incorrect because the forecasted timing, duration, volatility, and change in the possible direction of the expected cash flows must be considered for a capital investment.
answerFeedback.f0f8d0a8-a6b6-4bbf-9b2b-9d26f268e595: Incorrect because managers must reflect the impact of taxation on a project’s expected cash flows, specifically the tax benefits derived from non-cash deductions, such as depreciation and amortization.
answerFeedback.fc2f9d5c-cc7e-486e-b389-ed270921a0ab: Correct because capital allocation analysis should ignore sunk costs, or those expenses that have already been incurred.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-McDonald-02
entry.itemBody: An individual can invest $50,000 today and receive $56,000 in one year's time. If her required rate of return is 12.0%, the rate of return on the investment is:

answerFeedback.755df99d-d7c8-4533-99d3-6db6dcef53f9: Incorrect because the return on the investment is mistakenly calculated as (56,000 – 50,000)/56,000 = 6,000/56,000 ≈ 10.7%, which is less than the required return of 12%.
answerFeedback.9d67ba6d-e14d-4ce9-8843-611fb08bde67: Correct because the return on the investment can be calculated as (56,000 – 50,000)/50,000 = 6,000/50,000 = 12.0%, which matches the required return.
answerFeedback.ccf8923e-89af-4793-bcd9-c2b1a8dd3e0e: Incorrect because the return on the investment can be calculated as (56,000 – 50,000)/50,000 = 6,000/50,000 = 12.0%. Therefore, it matches the required return but does not exceed it.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the required rate of return.
B. equal to the required rate of return.
C. greater than the required rate of return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01516
entry.itemBody: The entire cost of an intangible asset is most likely expensed when incurred if the asset is:

answerFeedback.1be0ae38-64e2-4b8f-9ae6-8d7749fad541: Incorrect because when one company acquires another company, the transaction is accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting. Under the acquisition method, the company identified as the acquirer allocates the purchase price to each asset acquired (and each liability assumed) on the basis of its fair value. If the purchase price exceeds the sum of the amounts that can be allocated to individual identifiable assets and liabilities, the excess is recorded as goodwill.  Therefore, an intangible asset acquired through a business combination is more likely to increase the asset and owners' equity of the acquirer than those which are internally developed.
answerFeedback.5ba18024-8f6a-405a-9ff7-b60d31c8afc6: Correct because the costs to internally develop intangible assets are generally expensed when incurred. There are some situations, however, in which the costs incurred to internally develop an intangible asset are capitalised. Because costs associated with internally developing intangible assets are usually expensed, a company that has internally developed such intangible assets as copyrights, patents, or brands through expenditures on R&D or advertising will recognize a lower amount of assets than a company that has obtained intangible asset through external purchase. IFRS require that expenditures on research (or during the research phase of an internal project) be expensed rather than capitalized as an intangible asset.
answerFeedback.ba7e44fc-8dfd-406c-9b14-2971cd3e24f6: Incorrect because intangible assets purchased in situations other than business combinations, such as buying a patent, are treated at acquisition the same as long-lived tangible assets; they are recorded at their fair value when acquired, which is assumed to be equivalent to the purchase price.

choices.itemBody: C. purchased in a transaction other than a business combination.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Econ 14RPG
entry.itemBody: An argument for a country’s high national debt relative to GDP being a concern is when the debt:

answerFeedback.01145013-f7e1-498b-88c1-8980bddbab0a: Incorrect because an argument against being concerned is a proportion of the money borrowed may have been used for capital investment projects or enhancing human capital (e.g., training, education); these should lead to raised future output and tax revenues.
answerFeedback.5a4a8760-a0ac-4943-852b-46b1ce99ddda: Correct because an argument in favor of being concerned is that government borrowing may divert private sector investment from taking place (an effect known as crowding out); if there is a limited amount of savings to be spent on investment, then larger government demands will lead to higher interest rates and lower private sector investing.
answerFeedback.b34347fc-8429-4cd0-b5c4-fa1505df93ec: Incorrect because an argument against being concerned is that the scale of the problem may be overstated because the debt is owed internally to fellow citizens.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-CorpIssuers-Kashyap-15
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in £ millions) about three companies:

  Company 1 Company 2 Company 3
Days of inventory 45 62 50
Days sales outstanding 30 45 53
Days of payables 25 60 48

The company with the shortest cash conversion cycle is:

answerFeedback.143082e7-6169-4048-9161-43b23bd2a206:
Correct because Company 2 has the shortest cash conversion cycle (CCC)

CCC = days of inventory + days sales outstanding – days of payables:

Company 1 CCC = 45 + 30 – 25 = 50.

Company 2 CCC = 62 + 45 – 60 = 47.

Company 3 CCC = 50 + 53 – 48 = 55.
answerFeedback.40519278-a327-4066-8efb-af14a90df3dc: Incorrect because Company 2 has the shortest cash conversion cycle.
answerFeedback.b54572b2-70fc-4fcf-a822-8f5dbf3f5eec: Incorrect because Company 2 has the shortest cash conversion cycle.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531128
entry.itemBody: Which of the following factors is most likely to lead to economies of scale?

answerFeedback.21e7adc0-374c-4052-846b-da3cfc912e79: Incorrect because duplication of product lines is a diseconomy.
answerFeedback.40300e13-5519-420d-adbb-36efce1aae77: Correct because specialization by workers can increase their proficiency, leading to lower average costs when the firm is large enough to allow specialization.
answerFeedback.420112be-9334-46b1-a42f-8f504d852fc1: Incorrect because supply constraints lead to higher resource prices, creating diseconomies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09729
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € thousands) about a company's total current assets:

Cash 300
Short-term marketable investments 400
Receivables 100
Inventory 200

If the current ratio is 1.0, the quick ratio is:

answerFeedback.71b899d3-9097-4194-887d-d3cbfdcaea25: Incorrect because it incorrectly calculates Quick ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable investments + Inventory) / Current liabilities = (300 + 400 + 200)/1,000 = 0.9.
answerFeedback.c5ad9e2f-d0dd-47fd-be93-24049832a6f5: Incorrect because it incorrectly calculates Quick ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable investments) / Current liabilities = (300 + 400)/1,000 = 0.7, which is the Cash ratio.
answerFeedback.c69027b9-063b-435a-bae8-ae77ae5c3167:
Correct because Current ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable investments + Receivables + Inventory) / Current liabilities

Rearranging gives Current liabilities = 1.0 × (300 + 400 + 100 + 200) = 1,000.

Quick ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable investments + Receivables) / Current liabilities = (300 + 400 + 100)/1,000 = 0.8.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Quant-Tsependa-05
entry.itemBody: The bootstrap resampling method:

answerFeedback.03347e85-032e-4341-943b-b9b9e593120c: Correct because the bootstrap mimics the (simple random sampling) process by treating the randomly drawn sample as if it were the population.
answerFeedback.103d32fc-e9b9-4171-bef5-1a105a335fac: Incorrect because in bootstrap, we repeatedly draw samples from the original sample, and each resample is of the same size as the original sample. Note that although some items may appear several times in the resamples, other items may not appear at all. Thus, bootstrap does not guarantee that all items will appear in the resamples.
answerFeedback.daa916ef-1453-42b3-a494-7ca7711448b7: Incorrect because compared with conventional statistical methods, bootstrap does not rely on an analytical formula to estimate the distribution of the estimators.

choices.itemBody: A. guarantees that all items will appear in the resamples.
B. relies on an analytical formula to estimate the distribution of the estimators.
C. mimics the random sampling process by treating the randomly drawn sample as if it were the population.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531120
entry.itemBody:
Assume the percentage increases in each of the following listed items:
  Percentage Increase
Real domestic exchange rate (USD/EUR) 5
Eurozone price level 2
US price level 1.5

The predicted change in the nominal US spot exchange rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.8110e991-8232-415f-80b4-c1f415fe768d: Incorrect because the change in the price levels are inverted: (1 + 5%) × [(1 + 2%)/(1 + 1.5%)] – 1 = 5.5%.
answerFeedback.a5948487-e55c-41f8-aeae-c98f10a5f29a: Incorrect because the change in the real exchange rate is not included: [(1 + 1.5%)/(1 + 2%)] – 1 = –0.5%.
answerFeedback.b4ded9c6-861f-433c-b836-f21e1ad50da5:
Correct. Change in the nominal exchange rate:

= (1+%ΔReal Exchange rate(USD/EUR)) × [(1+%ΔUS price level)/(1+%ΔEurozone price level)] – 1 

= (1+5%) × [(1+1.5%)/(1+2%)] – 1

= 4.5%

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FRA-Taylor-02
entry.itemBody: A company is prohibited from reversing the impairment loss on a long-lived asset classified as:

answerFeedback.8516ba53-567b-4057-8c95-1e3867a22e31: Incorrect because IFRS permit impairment losses to be reversed if the recoverable amount of an asset increases regardless of whether the asset is classified as held for use or held for sale. Note that IFRS permits the reversal of impairment losses only.
answerFeedback.c2380f1f-4743-4ae0-a8b9-2188f6a9241f: Incorrect because under US GAAP, the accounting for reversals of impairments depends on whether the asset is classified as held for use or held for sale. For assets held for sale, if the fair value increases after an impairment loss, the loss can be reversed.
answerFeedback.fef870a3-5b19-4821-a58f-b5a22d345f28: Correct because under US GAAP, once an impairment loss has been recognized for assets held for use, it cannot be reversed. In other words, once the value of an asset held for use has been decreased by an impairment charge, it cannot be increased.

choices.itemBody: B. held for use under US GAAP.
C. held for sale under US GAAP.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03907
entry.itemBody: Unaudited financial statements are most likely presented in a(n):

answerFeedback.9f02e851-a12b-4577-976e-7b0eaff0fc2e: Incorrect because the Auditor's Report is generally provided to shareholders at least annually.
answerFeedback.ca14bc9c-7ebf-4d2a-b4ca-49effbc5d0a2: Correct because interim reports are also provided by the company either semiannually or quarterly, depending on the applicable regulatory requirements. Interim reports generally present the four basic financial statements and condensed notes but are not audited.
answerFeedback.e2255e74-0479-4018-ab73-9544708ff8e0: Incorrect because the Auditor's Report is generally provided to shareholders at least annually. In addition, companies also provide information on management and director compensation, company stock performance, and any potential conflicts of interest that may exist between management, the board, and shareholders. This information may appear in the company's annual report or other publicly available documents. Public companies often provide this information in proxy statements, which are statements distributed to shareholders about matters that are to be put to a vote at the company's annual (or special) meeting of shareholders. Accordingly, the proxy statement provides other information and generally does not provide unaudited (or audited) financial statements.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-CorpIssuers-Leonida-10
entry.itemBody: From the perspective of a corporate issuer, which of the following is a benefit of issuing debt rather than equity as a source of capital? Debt is most likely:

answerFeedback.0bc3f704-85cf-49db-ba7f-d82039ce494e: Incorrect because equity holders represent a more permanent source of capital and have voting rights to elect the board of directors, which oversees the management of the company. Debt has a stated, finite term with generally no voting rights, while equity has no finite term and includes voting rights.
answerFeedback.5161e88c-056f-4d60-9ecd-dcfcc3bfd2ea: Correct because debt represents a cheaper financing source for companies and a lower risk for investors. Because the returns to lenders are capped and because the cost of debt is lower than the cost of equity, corporations with predictable cash flows may prefer to borrow money rather than sell an ownership stake to raise the capital they need to finance their investments. This is because issuing more equity dilutes upside return for existing equity owners given that residual value must be shared across more owners.
answerFeedback.8d16516d-6023-4593-a0ef-0296154add22: Incorrect because from the issuer’s perspective, bonds are riskier than stocks for the same reason bonds are safer than stocks for investors. Bonds increase risk to the corporation by increasing leverage. If the company is struggling and cannot meet its promised obligations to bondholders, bondholders have the legal standing to force certain actions upon the corporation, such as bankruptcy and liquidation.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608075
entry.itemBody: Compared with its net income, a mature company’s operating cash flow is most likely:

answerFeedback.214d300a-b88d-4391-b466-700775a91d74: Incorrect. For a mature company, net income includes non-cash expenses (depreciation and amortization), so it is expected and desirable for operating cash flow exceeds net income. If operating cash flows were lower than net income, this would be an indication of poor earnings quality.
answerFeedback.807ce448-fecc-4ec9-8251-7efa29403eef: Incorrect. For a mature company, net income includes non-cash expenses (depreciation and amortization), so it is expected and desirable for operating cash flow to exceed net income, not for them to be equal.
answerFeedback.f4f18065-93e9-4974-b6d7-9dd3aae7ba10: Correct. For a mature company, because net income includes non-cash expenses (depreciation and amortization), operating cash flow typically exceeds net income.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Tsependa-12
entry.itemBody: In hypothesis testing, which of the following is stated in terms of population parameters?

answerFeedback.26e0d02c-f7dd-4d41-8cae-d4ceaff17db1: Incorrect because the null and alternative hypotheses are stated in terms of population parameters, and we use sample statistics to test these hypotheses.
answerFeedback.bf8d09ad-4eb3-4826-82b6-296ee0c2f28e: Incorrect because the null and alternative hypotheses are stated in terms of population parameters, and we use sample statistics to test these hypotheses.
answerFeedback.d22e4528-1bfc-40bc-b499-89b9707f7a89: Correct because the null and alternative hypotheses are stated in terms of population parameters, and we use sample statistics to test these hypotheses.

choices.itemBody: C. Both the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02154
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in £ millions) from a company's year-end balance sheet:

  Year 2 Year 1
Accounts receivable 65 55
Inventory 120 140
PP&E 1,400 1,400
Accumulated depreciation 120 80
Accounts payable 25 40

During Year 2, net income was £860 million. There were no acquisitions or sales of property, plant, and equipment and no write-downs. Cash flow from operating activities (in £ millions) for Year 2 is:

answerFeedback.afa3e704-e5e9-4e5f-a1e7-aa02b7b54990: Correct because using the indirect method, operating cash flow is calculated as net income + depreciation expense – increase in current operating asset accounts (accounts receivable) + decrease in current operating asset account (inventory) – decrease in current operating liability accounts (accounts payable) = 860 + 40 – 10 + 20 – 15 = 895.
answerFeedback.e4a2d0ca-bb3f-45f5-b447-d1a8793696b7: Incorrect because the decrease in accounts payable is incorrectly added rather than subtracted: 860 + 40 – 10 + 20 + 15 = 925.
answerFeedback.e79c82d2-d832-4ed1-b0fd-a78b748cdaa8: Incorrect because the decrease in inventory is incorrectly subtracted rather than added: 860 + 40 – 10 – 20 – 15 = 855. This is also equal to the amount which ignores the depreciation expense: 860 –10 + 20 – 15 = 855.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-FRA-Pitrakkou-17
entry.itemBody: Costs incurred during the development phase that are related to internally generated, identifiable intangible assets:

answerFeedback.52e6dd83-76e1-47a3-993f-70ea1f97901a: Incorrect because costs incurred in the development stage can be capitalized as intangible assets if certain criteria are met, including technological feasibility, the ability to use or sell the resulting asset, and the ability to complete the project.
answerFeedback.614e904a-573d-4a3c-88c7-a887a9653e4f: Incorrect because costs incurred in the development stage can be capitalized as intangible assets if certain criteria are met, including technological feasibility, the ability to use or sell the resulting asset, and the ability to complete the project.
answerFeedback.a0e660e1-f517-49da-a3e9-24e33fc03751: Correct because costs incurred in the development stage can be capitalized as intangible assets if certain criteria are met, including technological feasibility, the ability to use or sell the resulting asset, and the ability to complete the project.

choices.itemBody: C. can be capitalized if certain criteria are met.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Quant-Croitoru-13
entry.itemBody:
An analyst runs a simple linear regression using 35 months of data to assess a country's short-term interest rate as a function of its inflation rate, with the following results:

Source Degrees of Freedom Sums of Squares Mean Square
Regression 1 17.3009 17.3009
Error 33 20.2299 0.6130
Total 34 37.5308  

The value of the standard error of the estimate is closest to:

answerFeedback.02c22cb7-3b40-46bc-8729-caced8c75d56: Incorrect because it incorrectly considers the standard error of the estimate as the square root of the coefficient of determination, which is calculated as the sum of square regression/sum of squares total: = 17.3009/37.5308 = 0.461. Then 0.4610.5 = 0.6789 ≈ 0.68.
answerFeedback.03fa335d-c74d-4bf4-905f-70ae75d93174: Correct because the standard error of the estimate in a linear regression is the square root of the mean square error, thus 0.61300.5 = 0.7829 ≈ 0.78.
answerFeedback.20cb6fb8-6013-4cb0-9eb2-810aa32c6d3e: Incorrect because it is the sample standard deviation of the dependent variable, computed as the square root of the total variation of the dependent variable divided by the number of observations minus one: (37.5308/34)0.5 = 1.0506 ≈ 1.05.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-CorpIssuers-Kassem-06
entry.itemBody: If the cost of capital exceeds the return on invested capital, shareholder value will:

answerFeedback.16aa9511-acd6-445f-995a-2839bdd81e0f: Correct because if the ROIC measure is higher than the COC, the company is generating a higher return for investors compared with the required return, thereby increasing the firm’s value for shareholders. The inverse is true if the COC is higher than the ROIC.
answerFeedback.1b52d4a7-9323-4ad4-9170-6a58f170053a: Incorrect because if the ROIC measure is higher than the COC, the company is generating a higher return for investors compared with the required return, thereby increasing the firm’s value for shareholders. The inverse is true if the COC is higher than the ROIC.
answerFeedback.e1333afa-4f20-45d4-9943-0d0bcb0133b1: Incorrect because if the ROIC measure is higher than the COC, the company is generating a higher return for investors compared with the required return, thereby increasing the firm’s value for shareholders. The inverse is true if the COC is higher than the ROIC.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-FRA-Ng-04
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € thousands) about an electronics manufacturing company: 

  Year 2 Year 1
Cost of sales 1000 800
Cost of ending inventory 150 120
Net realizable value of inventory 125 160

Changes to the allowance for inventory obsolescence have already been reflected in cost of sales. The days of inventory on hand (based on average inventory and 365-day year) for Year 2 is closest to:

answerFeedback.ce310c92-4d6f-41b2-b44e-55cd67243e92: Incorrect because inventories in both years were measured at cost instead of the lower of cost and net realizable value. Hence, Inventory turnover ratio = 1,000 / [(150 + 120) / 2] = 1,000 / 135 ≈ 7.407; and Days of inventory on hand = 365 / 7.407 = 49.3 ≈ 49.
answerFeedback.edbf8a34-5a1b-49c6-9edb-ab6c8059e659: Incorrect because inventories in both years were measured at net realizable value instead of the lower of cost and net realizable value. Hence, Inventory turnover ratio = 1,000 / [(125 + 160) / 2] = 1,000 / 142.5 ≈ 7.018; and Days of inventory on hand = 365 / 7.018 = 52.0 ≈ 52.
answerFeedback.fc01ef6c-0af2-40ce-a3d2-bff8b3f7a607: Correct because IFRS state that inventories shall be measured (and carried on the balance sheet) at the lower of cost and net realizable value; Inventory turnover ratio = Cost of sales ÷ Average inventory and Days of inventory on hand = Number of days in period / Inventory turnover ratio. Accordingly, Inventory turnover ratio = 1,000 / [(125 + 120) / 2] ≈ 8.163; and Days of inventory on hand = Number of days in period / Inventory turnover ratio = 365 / 8.163 = 44.7 ≈ 45.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531144
entry.itemBody: The effectiveness of infrastructure spending as a near-term fiscal stimulant would be least constrained by the:

answerFeedback.04fbec0c-9a1c-4d76-ae1f-b0afc01920ec: Incorrect because the action lag refers to the length of time required to actually implement a policy action once it has been decided on. In the case of infrastructure spending, it may take several months of planning before the project is put into action, thereby constraining its near-term stimulative effect.
answerFeedback.5286608b-7ae7-4f2f-8e26-a413d83594c1: Correct because recognition lag refers to the time required before policymakers realize that a policy action is required because data appear with a considerable lag and are subject to substantial revision. A policy action to spend on infrastructure would occur at the conclusion of this lag and, as a result, the recognition lag is not a constraint on any specific type of policy action.
answerFeedback.9d9bec9c-48fe-4514-b043-5eed75dd8f41: Incorrect because the impact lag refers to the length of time required for a policy action to become evident in the economy. When spending on an infrastructure project begins, there will be a delay in judging its effects and making any related adjustments to more effectively stimulate the economy due to the impact lag.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06539
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € millions) about a company's land reported under the revaluation model:

Original cost 12
Fair market value at initial revaluation on 31 December Year 1 17
Fair market value at second revaluation on 31 December Year 2 12

As a result of the second revaluation, the company recognizes in Year 2:

answerFeedback.20e6cc70-8014-410c-a34b-9288944061b2: Correct because if a revaluation initially increases the carrying amount of the asset class, the increase in the carrying amount of the asset class bypasses the income statement and goes directly to equity under the heading of revaluation surplus. Any subsequent decrease in the asset's value first decreases the revaluation surplus and then goes to income. Under IFRS, other comprehensive income includes certain changes in the value of long-lived assets that are measured using the revaluation model rather than the cost model. After initial revaluation, the revaluation surplus is thus 17 – 12 = 5. The second revaluation decreases the revaluation surplus by 5.
answerFeedback.74f6a2cf-df3b-449d-a491-f0e1b939f8ea: Incorrect because it assumes that the second revaluation impacts the income statement rather than the revaluation surplus account. If a revaluation initially increases the carrying amount of the asset class, the increase in the carrying amount of the asset class bypasses the income statement and goes directly to equity under the heading of revaluation surplus. Any subsequent decrease in the asset's value first decreases the revaluation surplus and then goes to income.
answerFeedback.8aadf3f1-524f-44b9-9b88-d594ad9d74c3: Incorrect because it compares the result of the second revaluation to the initial cost, thus resulting in neither a loss on the income statements nor a decrease in the revaluation surplus account. If a revaluation initially increases the carrying amount of the asset class, the increase in the carrying amount of the asset class bypasses the income statement and goes directly to equity under the heading of revaluation surplus. Any subsequent decrease in the asset's value first decreases the revaluation surplus and then goes to income.

choices.itemBody: A. a €5 million loss on the income statement.
B. a €5 million loss in other comprehensive income.
C. neither a loss on the income statement nor a loss in other comprehensive income.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Quant-Huffman-02
entry.itemBody: The goal of ordinary least squares regression is to minimize the sum of the squared deviations between the observations of the dependent variable and the corresponding:

answerFeedback.373a90dd-179f-4461-94fe-9138dcbb727c: Correct because the goal is to fit a line to the observations on Y and X to minimize the squared deviations from the line; this is the least squares criterion—hence, the name least squares regression. Because of its common use, linear regression is often referred to as ordinary least squares (OLS) regression. That is, we estimate the regression line as the line that best fits the observations. In simple linear regression, the estimated intercept, b0, and slope, b1, are such that the sum of the squared vertical distances from the observations to the fitted line is minimized. The focus is on the sum of the squared differences between the observations on Yi and the corresponding estimated value of the dependent variable.
answerFeedback.cad33506-277e-4b9a-9a17-2854cc0395c0: Incorrect because in simple linear regression, the estimated intercept, b0, and slope, b1, are such that the sum of the squared vertical distances from the observations to the fitted line is minimized. The focus is on the sum of the squared differences between the observations on Yi (dependent variable) and the corresponding estimated value of the dependent value. Further, the residual for the ith observation, ei, is how much the observed value of Yi differs from the Yi estimated value using the regression line. Note the subtle difference between the error term and the residual: The error term refers to the true underlying population relationship, whereas the residual refers to the fitted linear relation based on the sample. Fitting the line requires minimizing the sum of the squared residuals.
answerFeedback.f860f1c6-f9eb-4877-bea4-15f606cc3fd3: Incorrect because in simple linear regression, the estimated intercept, b0, and slope, b1, are such that the sum of the squared vertical distances from the observations to the fitted line is minimized. The focus is on the sum of the squared differences between the observations on Yi (dependent variable) and the corresponding estimated value of the dependent value.

choices.itemBody: A. estimated values of the dependent variable.
B. observed values of the independent variable.
C. values of the true underlying dependent variable.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-FRA-Terry-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a motivation for leasing long term rather than purchasing a high-value asset?

answerFeedback.5946deee-0e46-486a-acde-baf8fdcaf5e0: Incorrect because under IFRS, there is a single accounting model for both finance and operating leases for lessees. At lease inception, the lessee records a lease payable liability and a “right-of-use” (ROU) asset on its balance sheet, both equal to the present value of future lease payments.
answerFeedback.8363b695-70b3-4c66-a9f5-8a4926e3037b: Incorrect because under IFRS, there is a single accounting model for both finance and operating leases for lessees. At lease inception, the lessee records a lease payable liability and a “right-of-use” (ROU) asset on its balance sheet, both equal to the present value of future lease payments.
answerFeedback.9e9ff458-3591-443b-8de2-07c7c237cc37: Correct because there are several advantages to leasing an asset compared with purchasing it. Convenience and lower risks associated with asset ownership, such as obsolescence.

choices.itemBody: B. Not having to recognize an asset on the balance sheet
C. Not having to recognize a liability on the balance sheet

entry.title: ITEM_20170608226
entry.itemBody: The most appropriate statement about financial ratio analysis is that it has limited use as an analytical tool for:

answerFeedback.3f4423ed-1a2e-49e0-9dda-bd9844fdab27: Incorrect. Financial ratios are useful for evaluating management.
answerFeedback.6b630c29-4d2c-4edc-bf4a-5daeda41ce4f: Correct. Financial ratio analysis is limited by the use of alternative accounting methods. Accounting methods play an important role in the interpretation of financial ratios. The lack of consistency across companies makes comparability difficult to analyze and limits the usefulness of ratio analysis.
answerFeedback.ec529fd1-9d5b-48ca-864e-14af39aa1a49: Incorrect. Financial ratios provide insights into microeconomic relationships within a company that help analysts project earnings and free cash flow.

choices.itemBody: B. comparing companies that use different accounting methods.
C. providing insights into microeconomic relationships within a company that help analysts project earnings.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-FSAN-Pirie-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following could result in a permanent difference between accounting profit and taxable income?

answerFeedback.01c34dab-c9b9-4c95-ac47-49dec3eb2ee3: Correct because permanent differences are differences between tax and financial reporting of revenue (expenses) that will not be reversed at some future date. Because they will not be reversed at a future date, these differences do not give rise to deferred tax. These items typically include: (1) income or expense items not allowed by tax legislation, and (2) tax credits for some expenditures that directly reduce taxes. Because no deferred tax item is created for permanent differences, all permanent differences result in a difference between the company’s effective tax rate and statutory tax rate.
answerFeedback.7e11f382-8a56-457b-bf5d-cd8ba3aef491: Incorrect because this difference results in a temporary difference. Temporary differences arise from a difference between the tax base and the carrying amount of assets and liabilities.
answerFeedback.dd7f53a1-b029-4bf5-b1d4-ac0de563209b: Incorrect because a tax loss carryforward may be used to reduce future taxable income. It is the result of temporary differences. Differences between the tax base and the carrying amount also result in differences between accounting profit and taxable income. These differences can carry through to future periods. For example, a tax loss carry forward occurs when a company experiences a loss in the current period that may be used to reduce future taxable income. The company’s tax expense on its income statement must not only reflect the taxes payable based on taxable income, but also the effect of these differences.

choices.itemBody: C. Difference between carrying amount and tax base of assets because of different depreciation methods

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10927
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following financial market information:

EUR/USD spot exchange rate 0.9876
180-day USD risk-free rate 1.00%
180-day EUR risk-free rate 1.20%

EUR/USD is the amount of EUR per 1 USD.

 

The 180-day EUR/USD forward exchange rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.40afc3fb-cb9e-4a65-9fe6-da55b970925e: Incorrect because forward rate is calculated as: F EUR/USD = S EUR/USD × (1+ i USD) / (1+i EUR) = 0.9876 (1 + 0.01 × 180/360) / (1 + 0.012 × 180/360) = 0.9876 × (1 + 0.005) / (1 + 0.006) = 0.98662.
answerFeedback.b0eb9a6f-195a-41dc-b6ec-b492efb09280: Correct because another way of looking at this is, given the spot exchange rate and the domestic and foreign risk- free interest rates, the forward rate is whatever value completes this equation and eliminates any arbitrage opportunity. Thus F EUR/USD = S EUR/USD × (1+i EUR) / (1+ i USD) = 0.9876 × (1 + 0.012 × 180/360) / (1 + 0.01 × 180/360) = 0.9876 × (1 + 0.006) / (1 + 0.005) = 0.99352 / 1.005 = 0.98858.
answerFeedback.f0480378-aeef-4df9-a7fb-dcf7a7f19a30:
Incorrect because 180-day time frame was not taken into account.

FEUR/USD = SEUR/USD × (1+i EUR) / (1+ i USD) = 0.9876 × (1 + 0.012) / (1 + 0.01) = 0.99352 / 1.01 =0.98956.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-CorpIssuers-Simsek-22
entry.itemBody: The static trade-off theory of capital structure most likely considers:

answerFeedback.c1e3e128-5703-4675-9c22-7793767070d1: Incorrect because agency costs of equity are not considered by the static trade-off theory of capital structure, but are considered in the agency theory, which predicts that a reduction in net agency costs of equity results from an increase in the use of debt versus equity.
answerFeedback.da3c5ee6-e625-40cc-8e99-d5d10ec74868: Correct because the static trade-off theory of capital structure considers only the tax shield provided by debt and the costs of financial distress. The static trade-off theory of capital structure results in an optimal capital structure that is somewhere less than 100% debt.
answerFeedback.eaf27626-962a-4558-acdc-9f87979160de: Incorrect because information asymmetry is not considered by the static trade-off theory of capital structure, but is considered by the pecking order theory. The pecking order theory, developed by Myers and Majluf (1984), suggests that managers choose methods of financing according to a hierarchy that gives first preference to methods with the least potential information content (internally generated funds) and lowest preference to the form with the greatest potential information content (public equity offerings).

choices.itemBody: C. the tax shield provided by debt.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00057
entry.itemBody: Which of the following can be calculated based on information from the balance sheet only?

answerFeedback.188aafdf-cc2a-4175-9276-e112c459ce5d: Incorrect because receivables turnover = revenue / average receivables. Accounts receivable is available from the balance sheet, but revenue is only available from the income statement.
answerFeedback.7832bc5e-c6da-4638-83bc-9d8a24edcd6e: Correct because quick ratio = (cash + short-term marketable investments + receivables) / current liabilities. All of this information is available from the balance sheet.
answerFeedback.d259fedf-4eef-410c-8eef-dfb28fa45121: Incorrect because the debt coverage ratio is CFO / total debt. CFO is not available from just the balance sheet as it is derived from both the income statement and the balance sheet. The preparation of the cash flow statement uses data from both the income statement and the comparative balance sheets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06039
entry.itemBody:
An investor is considering three investments:

• Investment 1 makes 20 annual payments of $50,000, starting one year from today.

• Investment 2 makes 25 annual payments of $45,000, starting today.

• Investment 3 makes annual payments of $40,000 indefinitely, starting one year from today.

If the investor's discount rate is 10% per year, which investment has the highest present value?

answerFeedback.0504de9c-61fc-4a86-bd1b-02517c7c6837: Incorrect because Investment 2 has the highest present value. Investment 1 is an ordinary annuity with a present value calculated as PV = A[(1 – 1/(1 + r)N)/r], where A is the annual payment, N is the number of payments, and r is the discount rate. Therefore, PV = $50,000 × [(1 – 1/(1.1)20)/0.1] = $425,678. Calculator solution (END mode): I/Y = 10%; PMT = 50,000; N = 20; solve for PV = 425,678. A candidate could choose this if Investment 2 is mistaken for an ordinary annuity such that PV of Investment 2 = 408,467. Calculator solution (END mode): I/Y = 10%; PMT = 45,000; N = 25; solve for PV = 408,467.
answerFeedback.6de27d0d-42c7-4557-a412-8b7c3e329730: Incorrect because Investment 2 has the highest present value. Investment 3 is a perpetuity with a present value calculated as PV = A/r, where A is the annual payment and r is the discount rate. Therefore, PV = $40,000/0.1 = $400,000.
answerFeedback.7321895c-f3b4-4bf9-a883-7ce2151abe5d: Correct because Investment 2 has the highest present value. Investment 2 is an annuity due with a present value calculated as PV = A[(1 – 1/(1 + r)N)/r] × (1 + r), where A is the annual payment, N is the number of payments, and r is the discount rate. Therefore, PV = $45,000 × [(1 – 1/(1.1)25)/0.1] × (1.1) = $449,313. Calculator solution (BGN mode): I/Y = 10%; PMT = 45,000; N = 25; solve for PV = 449,313.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-CorpIssuers-Harper-04
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most likely has the greatest access to capital?

answerFeedback.a501f2ff-81e6-4f5f-b37b-ce7227736440: Incorrect because general partnerships have limited access to capital due to the limited number of partners allowed in the organization. As with a sole proprietorship, potential for growth is limited by the partners’ ability to source financing and expertise and their collective risk tolerance because the partners are still personally liable for business losses and debt.
answerFeedback.c639a8c1-ccc2-40a3-8792-19b8a5ae63f2: Correct because corporations have unbounded access to capital.
answerFeedback.fe2c2df0-5456-4aa2-98bd-a09da4e8add3: Incorrect because limited partnerships have limited access to capital due to the limited number of partners allowed in the organization.  Capital and expertise are typically limited to what the partners can contribute, and limited partners usually grant managerial responsibilities to the GP, which entails risk. Partnership agreements are customized and often limit the transferability of ownership interest or expansion beyond a small group of partners.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-CorpIssuers-Tsependa-05
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's capital sources:

Target weight of debt 25%
Target weight of equity 75%
Before-tax marginal cost of debt 4%
Marginal cost of equity 12%

If the marginal tax rate is 20% and interest expense is tax deductible, the company's WACC is:

answerFeedback.01a69ab2-4509-47d0-a034-b39d9cc9e300: Incorrect because, instead of multiplying, it divides the cost of debt by (1 – t), thus calculating the WACC as wdrd/(1 – t) + were = 0.25 × 4%/(1 – 20%) + 0.75 × 12% = 10.25%.
answerFeedback.565b0a69-bd13-4f37-a46c-6361af705683: Incorrect because it ignores that interest expense is tax deductible and calculates the WACC as wdrd + were = 0.25 × 4% + 0.75 × 12% = 10.00%.
answerFeedback.7aba068c-f9fd-4d43-99f5-1a5e79ae97d3:
Correct because taking the sources of capital to be common stock, preferred stock, and debt and allowing for the fact that in some jurisdictions, interest expense may be tax deductible, the expression for WACC is:

WACC = wdrd(1 – t) + wprp + were,

where 

wd = the target proportion of debt in the capital structure when the company raises new funds; 

rd = the before-tax marginal cost of debt; 

t = the company’s marginal tax rate; 

wp = the target proportion of preferred stock in the capital structure when the company raises new funds [which is equal to 0 in our case]; 

rp = the marginal cost of preferred stock; 

we = the target proportion of common stock in the capital structure when the company raises new funds; 

re = the marginal cost of common stock.

Thus, WACC = 0.25 × 4% × (1 – 20%) + 0.75 × 12% = 9.80%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Moustra-05
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following probability distribution of a company's earnings:

Probability Earnings ($ millions)
0.25 100
0.70 300
0.05 600

The standard deviation of the company's earnings is closest to:

answerFeedback.933d2c2f-5c1e-450a-bac1-e3f3a7dd9043: Incorrect because the candidate incorrectly calculates the expected value as the unweighted mean, i.e. E(X) ≠ (100 + 300 + 600)/3 ≈ 333.33. Then the variance is calculated as σ2(X) = E{[X − E(X)]2 } = 0.25×(100 – 333.33)2 + 0.70×(300 – 333.33)2  + 0.05×(600 – 333.33)2 ≈ 13,610.72 + 777.62 + 3,555.64 = 17,943.98 and the standard deviation is the positive square root of variance, i.e. 17,943.981/2 ≈ $133.96 ≈ $134 million.
answerFeedback.9c0337b9-152c-44f4-8eab-f702f2326b88: Correct because the expected value is calculated as E(X) = P(X1)X1 + P(X2)X2 + … + P(Xn)Xn = 0.25×100 + 0.70×300 + 0.05×600 = 25 + 210 + 30 = 265 and the variance is calculated as σ2(X) = E{[X − E(X)]2 } = 0.25×(100 – 265)2 + 0.70×(300 – 265)2  + 0.05×(600 – 265)2 = 6,806.25 + 857.50 + 5,611.25 = 13,275 and the standard deviation is the positive square root of variance, i.e. 13,2751/2 ≈ $115.22 ≈ $115 million.
answerFeedback.b15328f1-461f-44d4-957a-7bf84ac20ca8:
Incorrect because the candidate omits the probabilities in the calculation of variance. 

The candidate calculates the expected value correctly as E(X) = P(X1)X1 + P(X2)X2 + … + P(Xn)Xn = 0.25×100 + 0.70×300 + 0.05×600 = 25 + 210 + 30 = 265. The candidate then incorrectly calculates the variance as σ2(X) = E{[X − E(X)]2 } ≠  (100 – 265)2 + (300 – 265)2  + (600 – 265)2 = 27,225 + 1,225 + 112,225 =  140,675 and the standard deviation is the positive square root of variance, i.e. 140,6751/2 ≈ $375.07 ≈ $375 million.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04953
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases a security for ¥500,000. If the value of the security declines by 10% over the first 3-month period and then increases by 9% over the next 3-month period, the holding period return over the 6-month period is closest to:

answerFeedback.14110131-9c25-47c3-bf19-51976973a484: Incorrect because it is the arithmetic (or simple) mean of the two three-month HPRs: (-10% + 9%)/2 = -0.5%
answerFeedback.14e4be79-b975-4723-8de9-50fa094284c9: Incorrect because it is the sum of the two three-month HPRs; −10% + 9% = −1%.
answerFeedback.ebbe4b42-86ea-4ce1-bbca-c78b19756181: Correct because, first, calculate the future value at the end of six months; FV3 = PV(1 + g) = ¥500,000(1 - 0.10) = ¥450,000. FV6 = FV3(1 + g) = ¥450,000(1 + 0.09) = ¥490,500. Second, calculate the holding period return over the six-month period as HPR = , (P1 - P0)/P0 where P0 is the initial investment and P1 is the price at the end of the holding period; (¥490,500 - ¥500,000)/¥500,000 = -0.019, or −1.9%. Alternatively, the first three-month HPR is −0.10 and the second three-month HPR = .09. The six-month HPR can then be calculated by geometrically linking the two three-month HPRs; (1 − 0.10)(1 + 0.09) − 1 = −0.019, or −1.9%.
